Title: Introduction to Problem Solving using Application Software
Description: Introduction to computer fundamentals; contemporary topics, such as security and privacy, and the Internet and World Wide Web. Problem solving, analysis and design using application software such as spreadsheets and word processors.
Keywords: problem solving, analysis, design, application software

Title: Introduction to Computer Science for Multidisciplinary Studies I
Description: Introduction to problem solving, analysis and design of small-scale computational systems and implementation using a procedural programming language. For students wishing to combine studies in computer science with studies in other disciplines.
Keywords: problem solving, analysis, design, procedural programming

Title: Introduction to Computer Science for Multidisciplinary Studies II
Description: Continuation of Introduction to Computer Science for Multidisciplinary Studies I. Emphasis on object-oriented analysis and design of small-scale computational systems and implementation using an object-oriented language. Issues of design, modularization and programming style will be emphasized.
Keywords: object-oriented programming, modularization, design, analysis

Title: Introduction to Computer Science for Computer Science Majors I
Description: Introduction to problem solving, the analysis and design of small-scale computational systems, and implementation using a procedural programming language. For computer science majors.
Keywords: problem solving, analysis, design, computational systems, procedural programming, CS majors

Title: Introduction to Computer Science for Computer Science Majors II
Description: Continuation of Introduction to Computer Science for Computer Science Majors I. Emphasis on object-oriented analysis and design of small-scale computational systems and implementation using an object-oriented language. Issues of design, modularization, and programming style will be emphasized.
Keywords: object-oriented analysis, design, computational systems, modularization, programming style, CS majors

Title: Advanced Introduction to Computer Science
Description: An accelerated introduction to problem solving, the analysis and design of small-scale computational systems and implementation using both procedural and object-oriented programming languages. Issues of design, modularization, and programming style will be emphasized.
Keywords: accelerated problem solving, analysis, design, procedural programming, object-oriented programming, modularization, programming style

Title: Theoretical Foundations of Computer Science I
Description: Proof techniques. Recursion and iteration. Specification of algorithmic problems and fundamental proof techniques in Computer Science. Discrete structures such as graphs, trees, strings, functions, and their computer representation. Counting, permutations. Random events. Conditional events. Applications in Computer Science.
Keywords: proof techniques, recursion, iteration, algorithm specification, discrete structures, graphs, trees, strings, functions, counting, permutations, random events, conditional events

Title: Introduction to Computability
Description: An introduction to abstract models of sequential computation, including finite automata, regular expressions, context-free grammars, and Turing machines. Formal languages, including regular, context-free, and recursive languages, methods for classifying languages according to these types, and relationships among these classes.
Keywords: abstract models, sequential computation, finite automata, regular expressions, context-free grammars, Turing machines, formal languages, classification of languages

Title: Data Structures Algorithms and Their Applications
Description: Fundamental data structures, including arrays, lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, and graphs. Algorithms for searching and sorting. Introduction to analysis of algorithms. Applications of these data structures and algorithms.
Keywords: data structures, arrays, lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, graphs, searching algorithms, sorting algorithms, algorithm analysis, applications of data structures

Title: Explorations in Information Security and Privacy
Description: A broad survey of topics in information security and privacy, with the purpose of cultivating an appropriate mindset for approaching security and privacy issues. Topics will be motivated by recreational puzzles. Legal and ethical considerations will be introduced as necessary.
Keywords: information security, privacy, legal considerations, ethical considerations, recreational puzzles

Title: Data Structures Algorithms and Their Analysis
Description: Fundamental data structures, including arrays, lists, stacks, queues, trees, hash tables, and graphs. Algorithms for searching and sorting. Introduction to the correctness and analysis of algorithms. For computer science majors and those interested in algorithm design and analysis, information security, and other mathematically-intensive areas.
Keywords: Data Structures, Algorithm Analysis, Hash Tables

Title: Intermediate Information Structures
Description: A continuation of Computer Science 331. Collision resolution in hash tables, search algorithms, advanced tree structures, strings. Advanced algorithmic tools for storing and manipulation of information.
Keywords: collision resolution, hash tables, search algorithms, advanced tree structures, advanced algorithmic tools, information manipulation

Title: Theoretical Foundations of Computer Science II
Description: Probability spaces, random variables, expectation, independence, concentration bounds, conditional probability, repeated trials, error bounds. Turing machines and finite automata. Deterministic, nondeterministic, and probabilistic models of computation. Languages, regular languages and regular expressions. Methods for classifying computational problems as decidable or undecidable.
Keywords: probability spaces, random variables, expectation, independence, Turing machines, finite automata, deterministic models, nondeterministic models, probabilistic models, decidable problems, undecidable problems

Title: Computing Machinery I
Description: An introduction to computing machinery establishing the connection between programs expressed in a compiled language, an assembly language, and machine code, and how such code is executed. Includes the detailed study of a modern CPU architecture, its assembly language and internal data representation, and the relationship between high-level program constructs and machine operations.
Keywords: computing machinery, compiled language, assembly language, machine code, CPU architecture, high-level program constructs, machine operations

Title: Computing Machinery II
Description: An introduction to hardware and microprocessor design, including the connection between gate-level digital logic circuits and sequential machines that can execute an algorithm and perform input and output.
Keywords: hardware design, microprocessor design, digital logic circuits, sequential machines, algorithm execution, input and output

Title: C++ Programming
Description: Introduction to the C++ language, with an emphasis on its advanced language constructs and features. Techniques for writing time and space efficient code will be considered.
Keywords: C++ language, advanced language construct, time efficiency, space efficiency, programming techniques

Title: Explorations in Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning
Description: A survey of artificial intelligence and machine learning tools to cultivate an understanding of their capability, utility, and societal/ethical/legal considerations. Popular APIs will be used to develop simple applied examples.
Keywords: artificial intelligence, machine learning, societal considerations, ethical considerations, legal considerations, APIs, applied examples

Title: Metacognition in Self-directed Learning Methodologies
Description: Remain current in Computer Science as this field evolves by developing a reflective life-long learning practice. Independent student work will include using a wide variety of sources and developing the ability to self-assess progress in learning and knowledge in topics related to Computer Science.
Keywords: metacognition, self-directed learning, life-long learning, independent study, self-assessment, computer science

Title: Computer Networks
Description: Principles and practice in modern telecommunications, computer communications and networks. Layered communication protocols and current physical, data link, network and Internet protocol layers. Circuit switching, packet switching, and an introduction to broadband multimedia networking.
Keywords: Computer Networks, Protocols, Telecommunication

Title: Programming Paradigms
Description: Examination of the basic principles of the major programming language paradigms. Focus on declarative paradigms such as functional and logic programming. Data types, control expressions, loops, types of references, lazy evaluation, different interpretation principles, information hiding.
Keywords: Programming Paradigms, Functional Programming, Logic Programming

Title: Human-Computer Interaction I
Description: Fundamental theory and practice of the design, implementation, and evaluation of human-computer interfaces. Topics include: principles of design; methods for evaluating interfaces with or without user involvement; techniques for prototyping and implementing graphical user interfaces.
Keywords: HCI, Interface Design, GUI Prototyping

Title: Introduction to Information Visualization
Description: Principles of information representation, presentation and interaction. Development of mappings from data to visual structures and exploration, navigation, cues, distortion and emphasis techniques.
Keywords: Information Visualization, Data Representation, Interaction Design

Title: Thinking with Data
Description: An introduction to tools and techniques for managing, visualizing, and making sense of data. Includes an introduction to data cleaning, basic statistics, exploratory visualization, sensemaking, and data presentation.
Keywords: data management, data visualization, data cleaning, basic statistics, exploratory visualization, sensemaking, data presentation

Title: Programming with Data
Description: A hands-on introduction to basic coding skills, including core programming concepts and the fundamentals of reading, writing, and executing code -- with a focus on data manipulation. Emphasizes important tools and practices for programming with data, including development environments, source control, and debugging.
Keywords: programming with data, data manipulation, coding skills, development environments, source control, debugging

Title: Introduction to Data Science
Description: An introduction to commonly used programming tools and techniques for managing, visualizing, and making sense of data. Human implications of data collection, analysis, and use, including ethics, privacy, and alternate ways of knowing.
Keywords: data science, programming tools, data visualization, ethics, privacy, alternate ways of knowing

Title: Computational Statistical Modelling
Description: Random variables and their probability models. The Central Limit Theorem and parameter estimation. Statistical modelling of univariate and multivariate data with applications to discrete and continuous data. Data transformations. Introduction to simulation-based inference including randomization and permutation tests.
Keywords: computational statistical modelling, random variables, Central Limit Theorem, parameter estimation, univariate data, multivariate data, data transformations, simulation-based inference

Title: Statistical Modelling I
Description: An introduction to statistical computing and Bayesian modeling. Topics covered include random numbers generation, system/process simulation and evaluation, numerical integration, constrained and unconstrained optimization, Bayesian inference framework, single and multi-parameter models, regression models, Bayesian hierarchical modelling, Markov chain Monte Carlo.
Keywords: statistical computing, Bayesian modeling, random number generation, system simulation, numerical integration, optimization, Bayesian inference, Markov chain Monte Carlo

Title: Ethics of Models Metrics Algorithms and Data
Description: Ethical frameworks pertaining to data science. Algorithmic fairness and bias. Explainable results in machine learning and artificial intelligence. Privacy and data governance for large datasets. Human implications of data science in Indigenous and underserved communities.
Keywords: ethics, algorithmic fairness, bias, explainable results, machine learning, artificial intelligence, privacy, data governance, Indigenous communities

Title: Essential Optimization
Description: Unconstrained optimization and constrained optimization. Linear programming. Graph algorithms (including shortest-path and min-cut/max-flow) and integer programming. Simulated annealing and evolutionary algorithms. Other aspects of optimization as time permits.
Keywords: optimization, unconstrained optimization, constrained optimization, linear programming, graph algorithms, integer programming, simulated annealing, evolutionary algorithms

Title: Statistical Machine Learning
Description: Core concepts of statistical machine learning, with an emphasis on the statistical background of the machine learning discipline. Classification and regression, nearest neighbours, Bayesian learning, decision tree, support vector machine, linear discriminant analysis, dimensionality reduction, and an introduction to neural networks.
Keywords: Machine Learning, Bayesian Learning, Neural Networks

Title: Data Management for Data Scientists
Description: Current mechanisms for data management. It investigates various types of data models for dealing with various types of data, including big data with all its V's (e.g., volume, velocity, variety, etc.). In particular, the current offering of the course covers, the conceptual model, the relational model, its standard query language SQL, and relational database design. Additionally, it covers NoSQL databases as well as ACID and BASE data management techniques, with emphasis on state-of-the-art platforms like HADOOP and SPARK.
Keywords: data management, big data, relational model, SQL, NoSQL databases, ACID, BASE, Hadoop, Spark

Title: Cloud-based Platforms for Data Science
Description: Introduction to local and public cloud-based systems. Virtualization and containers. Creation, management, and cloud-based deployment of applications which solve data science problems. Privacy, security, and performance.
Keywords: Cloud Computing, Data Science, Virtualization

Title: Data Science Capstone
Description: A substantial research project in the field of Data Science. The project will consist of all the elements in the data cycle: collection, cleaning, exploratory analysis, statistical and computational analysis and presentation.
Keywords: data science project, data collection, data cleaning, exploratory analysis, statistical analysis, computational analysis, data presentation

Title: Deep Learning
Description: Fundamental concepts in neural networks, convolutional and recurrent networks, as well as deep unsupervised learning. Common applications of neural networks and deep unsupervised learning.
Keywords: deep learning, neural networks, convolutional networks, recurrent networks, deep unsupervised learning

Title: Classical Physics
Description: Vector algebra; statics and kinematics of rigid bodies; Newton's laws of motion; conservation laws; collisions; rotational mechanics; computer modelling of physical systems; approximation methods.
Keywords: classical physics, vector algebra, rigid bodies, Newton's laws, conservation laws, rotational mechanics, computer modelling

Title: Modern Physics
Description: Special Theory of Relativity. Origins of quantum mechanics. Wave mechanics and applications. Nuclear physics and radioactivity.
Keywords: modern physics, special relativity, quantum mechanics, wave mechanics, nuclear physics, radioactivity

Title: Linear Methods I
Description: An introduction to systems of linear equations, vectors in Euclidean space and matrix algebra. Additional topics include linear transformations, determinants, complex numbers, eigenvalues, and applications.
Keywords: Linear Algebra, Determinants, Eigenvalues

Title: Linear Algebra I
Description: A rigorous introduction to the theory of vector spaces, with an emphasis on proof writing and abstract reasoning. Topics include fields, subspaces, bases and dimension, linear transformations, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
Keywords: Vector Spaces, Proof Writing, Linear Transformations

Title: Introductory Calculus
Description: An introduction to single variable calculus. Limits, derivatives and integrals of algebraic, exponential, logarithmic and trigonometric functions play a central role. Additional topics include applications of differentiation; the fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals and applications of integration.
Keywords: Calculus, Limits, Differentiation

Title: University Calculus I
Description: An introduction to single variable calculus intended for students with credit in high school calculus. Limits, derivatives, and integrals of algebraic, exponential, logarithmic and trigonometric functions play a central role. Additional topics include applications of differentiation; the fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals and applications of integration. Differential calculus in several variables will also be introduced.
Keywords: Calculus, Integration, Differential Calculus

Title: University Calculus II
Description: A concluding treatment of single variable calculus and an introduction to calculus in several variables. Single variable calculus: techniques of integration, sequences, series, convergence tests, and Taylor series. Calculus of several variables: partial differentiation, multiple integration, parametric equations, and applications.
Keywords: Calculus, Integration, Multivariable Calculus

Title: Discrete Mathematics
Description: An introduction to proof techniques and abstract mathematical reasoning: sets, relations and functions; mathematical induction; integers, primes, divisibility and modular arithmetic; counting and combinatorics; elements of probability, discrete random variables and Bayes' theorem.
Keywords: Discrete Math, Proof Techniques, Combinatorics

Title: Numbers and Proofs
Description: A rigorous introduction to proof techniques and abstract mathematical reasoning with an emphasis on number systems: functions, sets and relations; the integers, prime numbers, divisibility and modular arithmetic; induction and recursion; real numbers; Cauchy sequences and completeness; complex numbers.
Keywords: Proof Techniques, Number Systems, Abstract Mathematics

Title: Calculus for Engineers and Scientists
Description: An extensive treatment of differential and integral calculus in a single variable, with an emphasis on applications. Differentiation: derivative laws, the mean value theorem, optimization, curve sketching and other applications. Integral calculus: the fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, improper integrals, and areas of planar regions. Infinite series: power series, Taylor's theorem and Taylor series.
Keywords: Engineering Calculus, Optimization, Taylor Series

Title: Linear Methods II
Description: An introductory course in the theory of abstract vector spaces: linear independence, spanning sets, basis and dimension; linear transformations and the rank-nullity theorem; the Gram-Schmidt algorithm and orthogonal diagonalization; and other applications.
Keywords: Vector Spaces, Rank-Nullity, Orthogonal Diagonalization

Title: Logic I
Description: Sentential and first-order logic from both deductive and semantic points of view. Some elementary metatheorems.
Keywords: Logic, Deductive Reasoning, Sentential Logic

Title: Information Technology Ethics
Description: A critical and analytical examination of ethical and legal problems arising in and about information technology. May include hacking, online privacy, intellectual property rights, artificial intelligence, globalization and regulation issues, cheating in online games, and others.
Keywords: Ethics, Information Technology, AI

Title: Elementary Formal Logic
Description: Sentential and first-order logic, with identity and descriptions, from both deductive and semantic points of view. Completeness, compactness, decidability for sentential logic.
Keywords: Formal Logic, First-Order Logic, Deductive Reasoning

Title: Logic II
Description: Introduction to the metatheory of logical systems. Completeness, compactness, Lowenheim-Skolem, and undecidability theorems for first-order logic. Preview of non-standard models, second-order logic, and Godel's first incompleteness theorem.
Keywords: Metatheory, Completeness Theorems, First-Order Logic

Title: Introduction to Software Engineering
Description: Introduction to the development and evolution of software. Covers key conceptual foundations as well as key methods and techniques used in the different phases of the software lifecycle. Emphasis on both technical and soft skills needed for high-quality software and software-based products developed in teams.
Keywords: Software Engineering, Development Lifecycle, Team Collaboration

Title: Introduction to Statistical Enquiry for Data Scientists
Description: An introductory course in statistical literacy. Data collection methodology and import. Data properties trending to the probability modelling of data and computation with R. Relative risk and Odds Ratios. Statistical sampling theory applied to parameter estimation and the testing of statistical hypotheses. Testing of single and multi-populations. Regression and Design and analysis of experiments with R. Simulation-based inference.
Keywords: Statistics, R Programming, Regression Analysis
